displayed_text: Patient: So where would the poop bag be, doc? Doctor: One on one side. One on the other side. Patient: Oh, doc! That ain’t – ohhhh, doc! That’s a stanky situation, doc! Doctor: I – pfffff – this is why I know you, Mr. L_! Patient: Oh, man! Doctor: I know you’re not gonna jump into this. Let me tell you this. I know you. Patient: Oh, man! Doctor: When push comes to shove, and this is reeeeaaaalllly bad. Patient: Doc, I was just talkin’ about the piss bag. Doctor: I know, but your other problem is the poop! Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Even if you re-route the piss bag, you may not be able to get away from not re-routing the poop. It just depends.

Patient: Um, it’s gotten better. Definitely gotten better. There’s still, uh, the little lump here, like a cyst. So, saw the ear, nose, and uh, throat specialist, and I have that right here where it’s drained. So, he gave me some ointment, um, prescription ointment that I put on every day, a couple times a day. Uh, I go back to see him in January, and you know, he just said, you know, to monitor it and make sure if anything gets worse to call him immediately. Doctor: And do they think this is related to the teeth or? Patient: They think so. Yeah. Doctor: Do you know how long you’ve had that lump? Patient: Um, uh, it started in, in August, late August. I, I, can see that it shrunk. I can see… Doctor: Did they say it’s smaller? Patient: Much smaller, yeah. Doctor: Draining, or? Patient: Oh, yeah. It’ll drain a little bit, you know, every day. It’s kinda gotten, you can feel it’s a little hard right here, like a hard lump. Doctor: And you’re not on any antibiotics? Patient: No, no. So, they think it’s a combination of the Xgeva and the, uh, oral surgery I had a year ago. Doctor: Anything else going on?

Patient: Yeah I Doctor: Where were you now? Patient: I was down in Kentucky. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Mhmm. Sometimes I have to travel for the job. Doctor: That’s good. Was it hot? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Right now it must be boiling down there. Michigan is pleasant. Patient: Yeah compared to Kentucky, yes. Doctor: So next week I’m thinking if we get you authorized for this Firmagon injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay I can always cancel if I don’t need it.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I appreciate both of you coming in. I really do. Patient: Well, thank you. I appreciate the time that you spend. Doctor: Oh, of course. I just wanted to wrap everything, yeah, because, you know, this always happens in medicine, right, we have one path and we’re like we’re going this way, it’s like no, everybody to the left, everybody to the left. We’re just regrouping. We’re just regrouping. Thank you both. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: I’ll get all the paperwork, get your scans set up and I’ll see you guys next week. Patient: Alright. That sounds good. Saturday we’re still… Doctor: Oh, that’s great. Come hungry for breakfast because the buffet is like. Patient: Alright. Great. Doctor: Yeah, it’s the best part, I mean other than the speaker. Patient: Right. Doctor: See you guys.

Patient: Oh I got a little inflammation from the penis um well inversion you know and you’re gonna get urine up in there and it’s gonna get inflamed. I’ve been using my statin ointment and that helps somewhat, but uh… Doctor: I think you might need surgery to fix that problem. Patient: A surgeon? Doctor: Yeah a urologist. Patient: That sounds like fun. laughs]] Doctor: I know. Laughs]] Well it’s better than constantly dealing with this pestering problem. Family Member: The pestering is what it is. Doctor: Yeah, you shouldn’t just sit on it. Family Member: That’s what I told him, I said it’s gonna fall off if you don’t do something. Laughs]] Doctor: No I don’t think, no but the things way more… Patient: Are we on tape right now? Ah, we’ll talk about that later. Doctor: No but I’m surprised, how many months have you been putting up with this? A lot of time? Like years? Family Member: No, no. Six months, eight months?

Patient: By whenever yeah, Doctor: Something like that, okay. Patient: two weeks ago today. Doctor: Yeah, okay. Let me give you the brief summary of what I think is happening because I know you like it itemized so we have a plan. One, your PSA’s going up but not unexpected. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because we talked about how Provenge just doesn’t touch that PSA. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But more concerning is just you have more lymph nodes or they’re not even technically lymph nodes they’re more… Patient: Nodules. Doctor: …nodules in the belly whereas before… Doctor: Yeah. It’s more of the schmutz that we talked about… Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Yeah. Since you took, you said that. Right, huh, huh, huh, right there. It feels like a, a scab. But then sometimes it feels like a, a needle. Doctor: But you can pinpoint it to the one place? Patient: Yep. Doctor: That’s a little dry skin there. Okay. Patient: And then you scratch it- Doctor: Anything else to look at? Any swelling or anything? Patient: No. Doctor: It looks, I know it’s got a little scab to it. Patient: Well, that’s because I take my fingernail and I scratch it. And the only reason I scratch it is because when your shirt hits it, it hurts. You told me to mention everything. Are these cameras on? Doctor: They are. Patient: With me, me running off at the jaws. Doctor: Today, your white count is fine. Your anemia is unchanged. So that’s normal when you’re on these medicines a lower testosterone. Your platelets are also normal. Kidney function looks good. Your albumin is better. Your alkaline phosphatase is the same. Everything else is normal.

Family Member: We stand, we stand in agreement with you. Doctor: Okay. But the good news is that you’re feeling well and the bone disease really did not get any worse. Family Member: Right. That’s good. Doctor: You know? You didn’t have any new areas, nothing else. Family Member: That’s a blessing. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Your pain and everything else overall is pretty well controlled. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So I’m good with that. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Alright?

Patient: Right. Doctor: Depending on what side. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They put a needle through – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Doc They take samples out – Patient: Okay! Doctor: And then when you’re done, they say, “Wake up, Mr. L_! You’re goin’ home!” Patient: I’m goin’ home. Doctor: And she’s gonna bring you home! And that’s the end! It’s all outpatient. Patient: Okay. Okay. Family Member: I’m not gonna be there. Patient: Okay. So, doc. So, doc. So, doc.

Family Member: How is his reaction or side effects kind of differ from the way they are right now. Doctor: Well, that's, you know, for Xtandi, it's the potential tiredness, a little balance issues, none of which has plagued you, but chemo is more chemo usual chemo type of things, like hair thinning or hair loss. Family Member: We don’t worry about that. Doctor: You can get neuropathy, you know, over time, which is numbness and tingling. Patient: I can’t get more than I got. Doctor: Well, I'm hoping it's not that bad, you're stable, but you know, if it gets much worse you're not even eligible for the trial. The other parts are, you know, we watch the liver function, we check by blood test. Some people get a weird taste in their mouth, not necessarily metallic, but just doesn't taste right. Family Member: In other words, when he eats it’s not going to be as wonderful. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: One of the things you enjoy. Doctor: But you know, if that's bad and we stop it and quality of life's terrible anymore Family Member: Well, with this neuropathy would this be something that would prevent him from being on this trial. Doctor: Well, you know, it’s yes, in the sense- Family Member: He definitely has it?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Anyway. Patient: Yeah. Uh, the last time that that you saw a spot or spots on my bone, you used radiation to go with it. Doctor: Right. Patient: So what, what’s the difference this time? Doctor: Well, I think we saw, you know, a few, you know, small number of spots. We thought like we could radiate them. Maybe those are the only spots. Patient: Right. Doctor: It looks like there’s more now. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I, I don’t think we could do that radiation. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, just because of the number of them. Patient: Right.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, based on your interpretation, perhaps they’re a little bit better. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not putting words in your mouth. Uh, so before I came in to see you today, I was kind of planning to say like this doesn’t look like it has been working that well, maybe we should switch to something else. After speaking to you, and hearing it from you, I’m kind of backtracking a little bit and I’m beginning to think like maybe we should give this a chance to work a bit longer. Um, you certainly haven’t had like the best possible response that we could have expected. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: We have seen patients who, even in the first two months, their PSA level drops by fifty percent, and the tumors begin to shrink. We certainly haven’t seen that. On the other hand, we haven’t seen like an obvious, uh, progression of the cancer either on the scans. So I would say, you know, you’re certainly not the best case scenario on this medication, but you’re by no means the worse, either, somewhere in the middle, and so that’s why I needed some input from you as far as what you think we should do. I’m willing to stick with this a little bit longer. We don’t want to wait too long so that, you know, if something bad happens like one of your bones fractures or pain gets excruciatingly worse, uh, and so, and on the other end of the spectrum as well, your anemia is still there, so your hemoglobin level was still below nine. It was about eight point nine, uh, on the most recent check, and even if we decided to continue on this study at the very least between now and your next visit- is that September fourth? Family Member: Fifth. Doctor: Fifth? We would need to, again, hold the drug. Because even at the lower dose of two-fifty, it’s still causing, you know, that significant anemia. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, I just want to get a sense from you whether you think you might, you know, want to stick with this for about two more months until the next set of scans? Whether you feel that you’ve had enough and you want to try something new? Or like where are you at with this? Patient: Well- Family Member: So, can I give you my perspective-? Doctor: Yeah. Please. Yes.

Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: Well, I think I’m dandy. The question is are you dandy? Family Member: Right. We haven’t got the blood work back yet, so. Doctor: Yeah. PSA’s not back. The rest of you is actually okay. Family Member: He was going through, he went through a rough time after radiation. You probably talked to the other doctor. I mean he was on his hands and knees with his head on the couch. And I went, J___, you need to go up and get in bed. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: He was pretty bad. Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: What is it? Patient: I was just checking. Family Member: Do you have any- Doctor: That is like, I’m going to shoot you. I’ll be right back. Okay boss. Patient: I was just checking.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, but hormone therapy, uh as far as I’m concerned, it’s the worst part of the whole thing, right. It’s gonna put you into menopause, it stills your sex drive, it gives you hot flashes, and it slows your metabolism by you know twenty-five percent, so you have to decrease your calorie intake. And you have to exercise like a fiend, or you’re going to get fat, and you don’t want that. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um but the other thing is it just makes you more tired, you know. We’re making you into an eight-year-old guy – Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: -temporarily. Family Member: For two years. Doctor: Yeah. Different people. I’m overstating it a little bit, but people are more tired. And uh, but people are more tired. And, and but if you exercise, it’s not as bad. Patient: Right. Doctor: And you don’t have the side effects of an increased heart attack risk. You don’t have, your bones don’t get soft, your muscles don’t go weak; you know exercise is the key here. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Um, but um some guys have bad hot flashes. And some guys get depressed because their metabolism down. Um, but make no mistake, people keep working; they keep enjoying life; they’re just more tired. Family Member: Uh hum.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, I’m planning on getting scans next week and seeing Patient: Okay. Doctor: You anyway. So, within a week or two, I’ll be able to tell you. Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: What we are doing. Okay. The Zytiga, now this is a very specialized medication because it’s for cancer. Okay. So, we will need to send it to a mail order pharmacy. There are these specialty pharmacies Patient: Mmm, Okay. Doctor: That deal with this medication. So, Patient: Because I’ve got a mail order through my job, too. Doctor: Which one? Patient: My mail order is called E-h-i-m. They deal with mail order prescriptions. Doctor: Okay. This one, though, has to go to a specialty pharmacy.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
